description: SOUTH HAVEN- Ron Wise has been putting out fires, responding to ambulance calls and leading one of Van Buren County's largest fire departments for most of his adult life. But after 31 years of being part of South Haven Area Emergency Services, Wise will be putting away his gear in exchange for retirement.  "My grandfather was fire chief for Niles Township and my...
text:
SOUTH HAVEN \- Ron Wise has been putting out fires, responding to ambulance
calls and leading one of Van Buren County's largest fire departments for most
of his adult life. But after 31 years of being part of South Haven Area
Emergency Services, Wise will be putting away his gear in exchange for
retirement.

Earlier this week in a changing-of-the-guard ceremony of sorts, Wise welcomed
Brandon Hinz as the new fire chief and director of SHAES. Hinz has been with
SHAES since 1999, starting as a paid on-call responder. He became a full-time
firefighter in 2005 and later served as an interim captain. He will now
oversee 16 full-time employees in addition to 30 paid-on-call firefighters, a
communication staff and seasonal beach safety interns, while Wise will serve
in an advisory role until his retirement officially begins at the end of
September. Then, he and his wife, Kim, plan to take a vacation.

"I'm going to Hawaii with my wife to celebrate our 24-year marriage
anniversary and my retirement," Wise said.

Wise comes from a long line of firefighters and first responders.

"My grandfather was fire chief for Niles Township and my father was a
firefighter for Niles Township, along with my twin brother, who is a fire
captain with Niles city and older brother a police officer in Indiana," Wise
said.

Wise first began his career with SHAES as a firefighter 31 years ago when the
department was much smaller, and simply known as the South Haven Fire
Department. He moved up the ranks to become captain, and 12 years ago was
chosen to lead the department, which by then had become known as SHAES  an
entity funded by and serving the city and townships of South Haven, Geneva and
Casco.

The department operates out of three stations, utilizing nearly 20 different
types of rolling stock, ranging from ambulances to a fire boat to a 93-foot
ladder tower. In 2019 the department responded to more than 2,000 calls for
assistance.

SHAES has come to be looked upon as a model for other communities to follow.

"I have traveled throughout the state of Michigan talking to other communities
explaining how SHAES is funded and how costs are shared," Wise said. "The
biggest hurdle that I see for those communities is trusting one another and
the willingness to work together. I am very proud to tell other communities
how great our communities work together on so many levels."

When Wise isn't wearing his administrative hat for SHAES, he can often be
found working alongside firefighters and paramedics during emergency
situations.

"He gets involved in actual fire-fighting when appropriate," said Tom Renner,
a former longtime on-call firefighter who now serves as the publicist for
SHAES. "He has retained his certifications to be able to be part of the
medical response team when needed. He'll even drive a fire truck to a scene if
the situation warrants."

This past summer, Wise was credited with playing a key role in saving the life
of an exhausted swimmer who had become caught in high waves in Lake Michigan.
Wise jumped into the water with a rope and wrapped it around the man, who then
was pulled to safety by two other firefighters who were on the South Pier.

"Doing the job to the best of my ability has always been the goal," said Wise
in response to why he thinks it's important to stay directly involved with his
staff. "Both of my parents stressed the importance of serving our communities
and helping others. ... My mother taught 4- H, Sunday school, Cub Scouts and
was Berrien County Youth Fair volunteer for many years. My father taught
lifeguarding, firefighter training and still is active on the Niles Township
fire department at the age of 84. He is still a volunteer at Berrien County
Youth Fair each year, along with myself and twin brother."

Firefighting has changed quite a bit over the past three decades, according to
Wise.

"The amount of training hours that is needed to get the initial training to
become a firefighter or EMT has increased greatly," he said. "Our fires burn
so much hotter and faster in homes today as compared to older days."

Some aspects of the job haven't changed much, such as dealing with tragic
situations.

"Any call that deals with children is the hardest to deal with," he said.

But helping people is what keeps firefighters and paramedics motivated.

"The ability to help someone in their deepest of times is very rewarding," he
said.

title: Changing of the guard at SH-area fire department
html:
SOUTH HAVEN - Ron Wise has been putting out fires, responding to ambulance calls and leading one of Van Buren County's largest fire departments for most of his adult life. But after 31 years of being part of South Haven Area Emergency Services, Wise will be putting away his gear in exchange for retirement.

Earlier this week in a changing-of-the-guard ceremony of sorts, Wise welcomed Brandon Hinz as the new fire chief and director of SHAES. Hinz has been with SHAES since 1999, starting as a paid on-call responder. He became a full-time firefighter in 2005 and later served as an interim captain. He will now oversee 16 full-time employees in addition to 30 paid-on-call firefighters, a communication staff and seasonal beach safety interns, while Wise will serve in an advisory role until his retirement officially begins at the end of September. Then, he and his wife, Kim, plan to take a vacation.

"I'm going to Hawaii with my wife to celebrate our 24-year marriage anniversary and my retirement," Wise said.

Wise comes from a long line of firefighters and first responders.

"My grandfather was fire chief for Niles Township and my father was a firefighter for Niles Township, along with my twin brother, who is a fire captain with Niles city and older brother a police officer in Indiana," Wise said.

Wise first began his career with SHAES as a firefighter 31 years ago when the department was much smaller, and simply known as the South Haven Fire Department. He moved up the ranks to become captain, and 12 years ago was chosen to lead the department, which by then had become known as SHAES – an entity funded by and serving the city and townships of South Haven, Geneva and Casco.

The department operates out of three stations, utilizing nearly 20 different types of rolling stock, ranging from ambulances to a fire boat to a 93-foot ladder tower. In 2019 the department responded to more than 2,000 calls for assistance.

SHAES has come to be looked upon as a model for other communities to follow.

"I have traveled throughout the state of Michigan talking to other communities explaining how SHAES is funded and how costs are shared," Wise said. "The biggest hurdle that I see for those communities is trusting one another and the willingness to work together. I am very proud to tell other communities how great our communities work together on so many levels."

When Wise isn't wearing his administrative hat for SHAES, he can often be found working alongside firefighters and paramedics during emergency situations.

"He gets involved in actual fire-fighting when appropriate," said Tom Renner, a former longtime on-call firefighter who now serves as the publicist for SHAES. "He has retained his certifications to be able to be part of the medical response team when needed. He'll even drive a fire truck to a scene if the situation warrants."

This past summer, Wise was credited with playing a key role in saving the life of an exhausted swimmer who had become caught in high waves in Lake Michigan. Wise jumped into the water with a rope and wrapped it around the man, who then was pulled to safety by two other firefighters who were on the South Pier.

"Doing the job to the best of my ability has always been the goal," said Wise in response to why he thinks it's important to stay directly involved with his staff. "Both of my parents stressed the importance of serving our communities and helping others. ... My mother taught 4- H, Sunday school, Cub Scouts and was Berrien County Youth Fair volunteer for many years. My father taught lifeguarding, firefighter training and still is active on the Niles Township fire department at the age of 84. He is still a volunteer at Berrien County Youth Fair each year, along with myself and twin brother."

Firefighting has changed quite a bit over the past three decades, according to Wise.

"The amount of training hours that is needed to get the initial training to become a firefighter or EMT has increased greatly," he said. "Our fires burn so much hotter and faster in homes today as compared to older days."

Some aspects of the job haven't changed much, such as dealing with tragic situations.

"Any call that deals with children is the hardest to deal with," he said.

But helping people is what keeps firefighters and paramedics motivated.

"The ability to help someone in their deepest of times is very rewarding," he said.
